Week 1

Week 2

title: DIMP Package
text: Deletion after IMPutation (DIMP) is an R package that serves as a wrapper around the mice package. It performs multiple imputation on a dataset, then removes the imputed values for a specified outcome variable. This approach allows imputed covariates to be used in downstream analyses while avoiding analysis on imputed outcomes, which can introduce bias when the outcome is not missing at random.

title: DIMP Package
text: Deletion after IMPutation (DIMP) is an R package that serves as a wrapper around the mice package. It performs multiple imputation on a dataset, then removes the imputed values for a specified outcome variable. This approach allows imputed covariates to be used in downstream analyses while avoiding analysis on imputed outcomes, which can introduce bias when the outcome is not missing at random.

title: DIMP Package
text:
3. R code

library(mice)
library(dimp)

# Create a mids object
exampledata <- airquality
mice_obj <- mice(exampledata, m = 5, maxit = 5, seed = 123)


 iter imp variable

# Deletion
mice_obj_deleted <- dimp(mice_obj, "Ozone") # datasets in this object have missing outcomes







Note



This package was created by Mark Asuncion, Ting Lin, John Fei, Luke Bai and Jason Dang as part of the group project for CHL 8010 F2: Statistical Programming and Computation for Health Data (Instructor: Dr. Aya Mitani) offered by the Dalla Lana School of Public Health at the University of Toronto (Fall 2024).

title: Zhengyang (John) Fei
text:
Hi, I’m John Fei,

a Biostatistics MSc candidate at the University of Toronto with an emphasis in Artificial Intelligence and Data Science. I also have the privilege to work as a Student Researcher at the Institute for Better Health, Trillium Health Partners, under the supervision of Dr. Simona Minotti.


My research spans areas including patient experience and hospital quality improvement, where I analyze large-scale survey data to identify factors influencing care outcomes, as well as biomarker analysis for juvenile arthritis, where I support statistical modeling and clinical interpretation in collaboration with healthcare researchers.


I earned my HBSc in Statistics and Mathematics from Toronto in 2024, where my passion for health science, data science, and education blossomed while working with Dr. Asal Aslemand and others.


Beyond academics, music has always been a source of joy for me. My favorite artists include: John Mayer, Guns N’ Roses, Linkin Park, and Jay Chou.
